text: Alan Turing proposed the concept of a universal machine in 1936, now known as the Turing Machine, capable of simulating any computation.
During World War II, Turing worked at Bletchley Park and played a pivotal role in breaking the German Enigma code.
Turing introduced the idea of the Turing Test — a method for determining whether a machine can exhibit intelligent behavior indistinguishable from a human.
In 1939, Turing worked on building electromechanical machines like the Bombe, designed to expedite the breaking of Enigma messages.
Turing published 'Computing Machinery and Intelligence' in 1950, posing the question 'Can machines think?' and laying the groundwork for artificial intelligence.
Turing envisioned the concept of learning machines — machines that could modify their own instructions based on experience.
Alan Turing also made early contributions to mathematical biology, studying the chemical basis of morphogenesis.
